TextView.android:text: Lesson 12 is another “breather” and introduces no new shorthand devices. It focuses on reviewing the strokes you learned in earlier lessons.
The following rules cover the joinings of the two forms of s:
1.At the beginning and end of words, comma s is used before and after f, v, k, g, while left s is used before and after p, b, r, l.
2. Comma s is used before t, d, n, m, o, while left s is used after these strokes.
3. Comma s is used both before and after ish, chay, and j.
4. Comma s is used in words made up of s followed by a circle vowel, or s followed by ith and a circle vowel.

5. Gregg Shorthand is equally readable on ruled or unruled paper, so you don’t need to worry about aligning your outlines perfectly with the printed lines in your notebook. The main purpose of the lines is simply to prevent your writing from drifting uphill or downhill.

To ensure uniform placement in the shorthand books, a general rule is followed: the base of the first consonant of a word is placed on the writing line. However, when s precedes a downstroke, the downstroke itself is placed on the line.
